## Steps to reproduce

```
PS> tr '\t' '    ' < in.txt > out.txt
```
## Expected behavior

it works
## Actual behavior

```
At line:1 char:16
+ tr '\t' '    ' < in.txt > out.txt
+                ~
The '<' operator is reserved for future use.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : RedirectionNotSupported
```

comments.author: ferventcoder
comments.body:
I take it back, it is working for me

``` powershell
rob@skylight $ /usr/local/bin/powershell -NoProfile -NonInteractive -NoLogo -Command - < ~/code/temp/hello.ps1
Hello from OSX
```

This method of input redirection (`- <`) has worked for years with PowerShell CLR, and it appears it still works with the new. 👍

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body: Input redirection to powershell works and is tested - it's just that input redirection doesn't work from powershell.

comments.author: bgshacklett
comments.body:
While this seems like a nice to have on the surface, there are some things that you can do in Bash that you just can't do in PowerShell at the moment. The biggest use case I have for this is with `diff`. For example: `PS> diff -u <(Get-Content -Raw one.json | jp *) <(Get-Content -Raw two.json | jp *)`

I work with a lot of JSON, and sometimes I need a textual diff. Doing so requires that the data be normalized first and I'd like to avoid creating temporary files to do this, especially in cases where the JSON data may contain sensitive information.

Also, this isn't just a Linux/Mac issue; its usefulness is just as significant on Windows.

comments.author: xa0082249956
comments.body:
I'm a little confused about the `future use` here.
Does that means `<` may not use as file redirection in the future version of PowerShell?

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: It means it was originally reserved in case they wanted it for that purpose, but was never implemented. I don't know if there are plans to implement the functionality natively into PowerShell or not.
